articles.author: Nathan A. Miller
articles.description: Where to go on the hottest day of the summer? The pool at Umpqua Community College was the choice for many Monday afternoon. As the temperatures soared to triple-digits, families enjoyed the refreshing feel of the Winchester waters.
articles.title: What to do when it is hot, hot, hot

articles.author: Joseph Ziegler
articles.description: Curtin drug bust nets 30 marijuana plants, meth, and firearms. Two men face charges, including manufacturing and possession. One suspect, a felon, was arrested for having guns. Six others were detained but released at the scene.

articles.author: Joseph Ziegler
articles.description: BLM has closed Susan Creek Campground Wednesday–Tuesday for a precautionary deep clean. The Susan Creek Falls day-use area and trail remain open. Officials say no norovirus is confirmed; crews are sanitizing facilities before reopening.
articles.title: Susan Creek Campground closed for weeklong sanitation; day-use area remains open

articles.author: Joseph Ziegler
articles.description: DFPA will lower the fire danger from EXTREME to HIGH on August 15, 2025, due to cooler temperatures and higher humidity. Public Use Restrictions remain in place, with limits on certain activities, open burning bans, and safety requirements to help prevent wildfires.
articles.title: Fire Danger Level Reduced from Extreme to High Across Douglas District

articles.description: Roseburg hosts its 3rd International Overdose Awareness Day on Sat., Aug. 23, 11 a.m.–1 p.m., Stewart Park Pavilion. Free, family-friendly event by Adapt, HIV Alliance and DPHN honors lives lost, supports recovery; theme: “One Big Family.”

articles.author: Ryan Bonham
articles.description: A 33-year-old Roseburg man was arrested Thursday after allegedly entering a local residence where he spent several hours and cooked food for himself before he was eventually arrested, according to the Roseburg Police Department.
articles.title: Roseburg burglar suspect entered home, cooked and ate food prior to arrest

articles.description: Starting on Friday, the Douglas Forest Protective Association (DFPA) is lowering the fire danger level from extreme to high due to predicted cooler temperatures and increased humidity.
